awd_titl_txt: High Performance Receiver Designs in Non-Orthogonal Multiple Access Networks for New Generations of Wireless Services
awd_abstract_narration:
This research project addresses some critical and emerging challenges in future generations of wireless communication networks to serve the need of the widespread Internet of Things (IoT) applications.  Unlike existing cellular networks, IoT applications are expected to connect a massive number of smart IoT devices under severe bandwidth constraint. This massive scale and need of IoT wireless devices, along with many other rising wireless applications such as vehicular to everything (V2X) strongly motivates highly effective utilization of network capacity.  To substantially expand network capacity, non-orthogonal multiple access (NOMA) is a cutting-edge technology that integrates the concepts of superposition coding at transmitter and successive interference cancelation (SIC) at receiver,  respectively.  NOMA has attracted much attention for its high spectral efficiency.  However, the NOMA throughput gain comes at the price of having to overcome substantial co-channel interferences (CCI) among wireless network nodes. Despite the widespread and idealized receiver assumption of perfect interference cancellation, practical success of NOMA receivers depends critically on the successful detection and decoding of signals in the presence of substantial CCI. This research project aims to develop highly effective and practical joint detection and decoding receivers to deliver the much needed network performance for successful deployment of NOMA in future 5G and IoT wireless services.  Specifically, the project develops optimized design of joint detection and error correction receivers by leveraging the knowledge of user forward error correction codes to substantially improve receiver performance against CCI under channel uncertainties. The research findings can contribute importantly to the service improvement of high speed wireless networks and to broadening their applications in many practical fields where quality, efficiency, and service decentralization are paramount. The success of the project can lead to new system designs, new tools, and results that can impact other science and engineering fields. 

The technical focus of this project is to develop a new receiver design methodology that unifies signal detection and forward error correction in multiple-input-multiple-output (MIMO) wireless communications and diversity networks against poor wireless channel conditions. Unlike traditional approaches, this new investigation into the rather classic but open problem centers on novel optimization formulations that can incorporate Galois field codeword constraints imposed by the forward error correction (FEC) codes within the maximum likelihood detection principle for unified receiver optimization. This novel framework is general and encompasses many wireless models, including distributed MIMO, opportunistic cooperative networking, and retransmission diversities as well as their integrations.  This innovative direction emphasizes critical integration of multiple constraints from incompatible fields through effective constraint relaxation and novel objective function formulation.  Reformulating the optimization of joint detection and decoding problems into convex optimization, the proposed approach to receiver design integration represents a fundamental and practical design paradigm that can fully leverage various practical signaling and code constraints for joint detection and decoding against channel and other non-idealities to achieve high performance, efficiency, and reliability.  To confront practical challenges of channel estimation errors and fast channel fading in wireless networks, the project team shall develop fast, effective, reliable, and robust algorithms for coded MIMO transmissions under strong co-channel interferences subject to different practical limitations and network configurations, with respect to complexity and performance tradeoffs. The research findings are expected to have significant broader impact on a wide range of wireless applications including high speed cellular, IoT, and V2X services.

por.por_cntn:
Traditional design of wireless receivers has found it difficult to jointly optimize signal demodulation and error correction decoding. The major obstacle lies in the incompatibility of signal processing in the complex field and error correction decoding in finite fields.  This project investigates high performance receiver designs for interference-limited wireless communication systems including multiple-input-multiple-output (MIMO) and non-orthogonal multiple access (NOMA) by effectively exploiting the underutilized forward error correction (FEC) code constraints. Our goals are to develop fast, effective, reliable, and robust algorithms for joint detection and decoding of MIMO transmissions under strong interference subject to different practical limitations and network configurations.

Specifically, major technical outcomes and accomplishments targeted joint receiver design to integrate MIMO detection and FEC decoder include

  • A more practical and low complexity joint detection-decoding architecture that is based on the semi-definite relaxation (SDR) principle.  This new SDR receiver can substantially reduce the receiver complexity for low-density parity check (LDPC) codes of longer lengths that are used in practical systems.
  • A novel design of a unified detection-decoding receiver that incorporates polar code constraints into a joint linear programming receiver for blind detection of 5G cellular PDCCH with substantial performance improvement and cost saving.
  • Improved reliability of successive interference cancellation (SIC) receiver to recover NOMA signals by deriving Euclidean constraints of forward error correction (FEC) codes.

We also achieved related major technical outcomes in the direction of interferenece managment and high spectrum efficiency. We developed a novel license assistant acesss for controlled cellular network access in unlicensed bands by exploiting inherent WiFi protocol features for seamlessd overlay integration. We also designed a radio map for resource management which provides information regarding spectral activities and propagation in wireless networks for interference mitigation. We proposed a federated learning model on computation, storage, energy and bandwidth limited mobile devices and an energy efficient edge processing framework for edge machine learning. We designed a new interference management method based only on network connectivity information and Riemannian optimization algorithms to solve the complex fixed-rank optimization problem. Furthermore, we developed a framework for blind signal recovery in non-orthogonal spectrum sharing to facilitate uncoordinated grant-free access of IoT nodes.

A number of peer-reviewed articles reporting these and other findings have been published in 13 journal papers and 3 conference papers.

  • Wirtinger Flow Meets Constant Modulus Algorithm: Revisiting Signal Recovery for Grant-Free Access.  IEEE Transactions on Signal Processing. 69:6515-6529. 

  • A Riemannian Geometric Approach to Blind Signal Recovery for Grant-Free Radio Network Access.  IEEE Transactions on Signal Processing. 70:1734-1748.

  • A Markovian Model-Driven Deep Learning Framework for Massive MIMO CSI Feedback.  IEEE Transactions on Wireless Communications. 21(2):1214-1228.

  • Joint Turbo Receiver for LDPC-Coded MIMO Systems Based on Semi-Definite Relaxation.  2018 IEEE 88th Vehicular Technology Conference (VTC-Fall).  1-5.   

  • Federated Learning via Over-the-Air Computation.  IEEE Transactions on Wireless Communications. 19(3):2022- 2035.  

  • Joint Detection and Decoding of Polar Coded 5G Control Channels.  IEEE Transactions on Wireless Communications. 19(3):2066-2078. 

  • Energy-Efficient Processing and Robust Wireless Cooperative Transmission for Edge Inference.  IEEE Internet of Things Journal. 

  • Enhanced LAA for Unlicensed LTE Deployment Based on TXOP Contention.  IEEE Transactions on Communications. 67(1):417-429.

  • Engineering Radio Maps for Wireless Resource Management.  IEEE Wireless Communications. 26(2):133-141. 

  • Enhanced Receiver Based on FEC Code Constraints for Uplink NOMA With Imperfect CSI.  IEEE Transactions on Wireless Communications. 18(10):4790-4802.  

  • A Joint Detection and Decoding Receiver Design for Polar Coded MIMO Wireless Transmissions.  2018 IEEE International Symposium on Information Theory. 1011-1015.  

  • Graph-Based Resource Sharing in Vehicular Communication.  IEEE Transactions on Wireless Communications. 17(7):4579-4592. 

  • On Non-Intrusive Coexistence of eLAA and Legacy WiFi Networks.  2019 Proceedings of IEEE International Conference on Communications.  1-6. 

  • Generalized Low-Rank Optimization for Topological Cooperation in Ultra-Dense Networks.  IEEE Transactions on Wireless Communications. 18(5):2539-2552. 

  • Data Shuffling in Wireless Distributed Computing via Low-Rank Optimization.  IEEE Transactions on Signal Processing. 67(12):3087-3099. 

  • A Survey on MIMO Transmission With Finite Input Signals: Technical Challenges, Advances, and Future Trends.  Proceedings of the IEEE. 106(10):1779-1833. 

The research findings have significant practical impact on the improvement of future wireless services and their applications in many practical fields where quality, efficiency, and simplicity are paramount concerns. The PI mentored and trained 7 PhD students and 1 MS student with the support of this research grant. To help create a diverse hi-tech workforce, two of the eight students are female and one is Hispanic. 3 have completed their PhDs and 1 has completed the MS degree. The project findings have been broadly disseminated through conference presentations, journal manuscripts, seminars, and group website:  https://www.ece.ucdavis.edu/~zding
